title: Nobody, repeat nobody, puts ketchup on a hot dog
review: There are thousands of hot dog stands in the Chicago area but I have to believe that Jimmy's Red Hots at 4000 West Grand Avenue, at Grand and Pulaski, is the epitome of what an old-fashioned, greasy-spoon hot dog stand is supposed to be. Established in 1954, it is a family-owned business that doesn't win any awards for decor. In fact, the best seat is probably your own car. It is a no-nonsense, no-ketchup, no-tables, get-in-and-get-out business with a short menu that is easy to memorize. What'll you have? All-beef Vienna hot dog with all the trimmings or a Vienna beef Polish sausage with fries? There are a few other options...double dog, tamales, combo (red hot and Polish sausage), double Polish or veggie dog with fries. Everything is wrapped in paper and tossed in a bag. It isn't pretty but its juicy and beefy. Remember, Jimmy's abides by the Golden Rule stated on a sign than hangs beneath the menu board (Never, ever, don't even think about it) and reiterated by Clint Eastwood in his Dirty Harry movie: "Nobody, I mean nobody, puts ketchup on a hot dog." At Jimmy's, a customer would rather order a glass of milk.

title: Red hots, Polish, fries--and tamales?
review: Jimmy's Red Hots has been doing business at the intersection of West Grand and Pulaski on Chicago's West Side for more than 55 years. Hey, they've been on that corner since before Pulaski was called Crawford. During that time, Jimmy's credo has been: No ketchup. The phrase was made famous by Clint Eastwood in the 1983 movie "Sudden Impact," when Eastwood's signature character Harry Callahan told a fellow cop who was chomping on a ketchup-filled hot dog: "Nobody, I mean nobody, puts ketchup on a hot dog!" At Jimmy's, the condiments don't include ketchup. Jimmy's is sparse in a lot of ways...one tiny room with people lined up to one side waiting to order and a long counter facing the windows on the other side, no tables outside and a very small menu of red hots, Polish sausage, soft drinks, fries and tamales. Call if an "on the go" cuisine. It is a no-nonsense, standing-room-only, get-in-and-get-out operation. The best seat probably is your own car. But it's a good bet that you probably haven't tasted better hot dogs or Polish sausage or tamales or fries anywhere else. Jimmy's uses all-beef natural casing dogs from Vienna Beef and the fries are freshly cut and fried twice. Two hot dogs with mustard and relish, French fries and a 32-ounce drink costs about $8. There are a lot of hot dog joints in Chicago--and every one of them has a cadre of devoted followers--but Jimmy's Red Hots has survived the test of time. This is an original.

title: Too much deliciousness in one meal, totally satisfied
review: This was our first time stopping in Feed for dinner. If you're from out-of-town, the location is a straight shot west of MagMile.  The Chicago bus lets off right out front.  It's in an industrial area and there's not much besides a bar or two...besides Feed.  Don't let this discourage you from going over there; it's worth the trip if you love hearty comfort food.   Right off the bat the staff was super friendly and helpful with suggestions from the menu of what was good that night.  We split a whole chicken with 3 sides and dessert for around $20.  The chicken was cooked very well but not dry, skin fantastic.  The mac n cheese was nice and creamy and light but not too cheesy.  I personally liked it that way, although others may be looking for a heavier/cheesier dish.  The homemade mashed potatoes were perfect.  The potato salad was heavy on the mustard and my friend loved it but I stuck with the black beans.  Ask to try stuff before ordering if you're not sure.  I'm pretty sure if their not really busy they'll help you pick something to your liking.    I wanted to try the corn pudding everyone raves about but the counter guy said not to as it was a bit dry late in the day.  I appreciate the honesty as he clearly wanted us to have a great first impression.  Friendly service is just as important as the food to me these days.   Finally, dessert was the triple berry pie.  I was very impressed with my slice. It was slightly heated with whipped cream and still retained a nice texture.  Usually heated berry pies get all runny and soupy on the plate.  Not too much blueberry, not too much blackberry made it very good.  At this point, I was ready for a food nap and we still each had over a half plate to wrap up for home.  Now I know it's not about the quantity but the quality, but when you're on a dining budget, it's nice to have a leftover lunch of tasty treats the next day.    This food is really really good, fair pricing and a casual comfortable setting to eat it in.  Thank you Feed, we'll be back to try that corn pudding soon.More

title: Overpriced and bad service_$16 for a standard plate of buffet food!?!
review: We had a profound and unresolved sense of being wronged, so I thought to post this review and let readers decide for themselves.  $16 for a plate of food that normally costs $9-$10!?!   We entered La Palma to discover the traditional buffet-style service sitting behind...the display case. Being Puerto Ricans from New York who currently live in Detroit, we have travelled extensively and eaten Puerto Rican food at many places. Never have I been charged $16 for ‚Äúmixing‚Äù offerings from the buffet. The plate we received was also the traditional 50-75% rice, so it wasn‚Äôt as if we received the ‚Äúextra meat‚Äù on our plate we were charged for. Despite raising the issue with the cashier and making an accounting that recognized the amount we were being charged, she assured us that her numbers were correct. I didn‚Äôt want to make my husband uncomfortable and spoil our meal by insisting that we had been overcharged. I wish I had... I wish we had left.  We also ordered the jibarito, which paled in comparison to the glowing reviews here. Like the rest of the meal, the flavors were not bland but were unremarkable. The place caters to a diverse palate, which translates into erring on the side of reducing the ‚Äúgarlicky‚Äù flavor that characterizes Puerto Rican food. I found the jibarito tasteless, but took half of my unconsumed meal home for the dog‚Ä¶even he didn‚Äôt want it.  We were further disappointed to learn that the order for the jibarito wasn‚Äôt communicated the chef, even though I had placed it over three times with the overstaffed locale that had servers, cooks and cashiers tripping over themselves. The mix-up was resolved as I waited and as my husband finished his meal, which made for a long meal with one or the other of us waiting as the other ate. My toddler didn‚Äôt much appreciate the extensive wait either.  In sum, we paid $26 for inadequate service, one plate of food, one jibarito, and one bottled soft drink. This price is comparable to a much more upscale restaurant, which was not appropriate for the relatively bland favors, unremarkable location, and backyard-style d√©cor we found here. Neither of us would return. We would never recommend La Palma to anyone we like.More

title: South Suburb Italian, which means good!
review: For those like me who grew up in the southern suburbs of Chicago and remember the glory days of Tivoli and Cipriani's restaurants, La Scarola will be one of those experiences of gustatory recognition - you know, when you taste something and immediately recognize a taste that you have not had for 20 years but remember exactly where it was that you had that taste before. The food is excellently made with authentic flavors and ingredients - no over-sugared marinara sauce here. Also no lack of butter and cream, so watch out!That is worth noting - the portion sizes are Rosebud-esque and so share with a friend or expect to bring half home. If you want an appetizer or wish to enjoy the excellent bread (served with great olive oil and parmesan for dipping), then that entree might be require a change to the belt loop. The eggplant parmesan was enormous, with cheese and sauce spilling over the edge of the plate. The sublime gnocchi (this version with sausage, asparagus and tomato in a a light butter sauce), was a mound of delight (see nearby picture).The decor is a throwback too - Italian- or Chicago-themed celebrity pictures from floor to ceiling, tables piled on top of each other, friendly waiters. Quite a different feel from nearby (also excellent) Piccolo Sogno. NOT Covid-friendly however!!!Highly recommended.

title: Don't forget to buy the book

There are so many positives. It is as good as advertised, even better. Located at 721 West Grand Avenue, in the River West/West Loop neighborhood, east of the busy Grand/Milwaukee/Halsted intersection, La Scarola is open from 5 to 11 Monday through Friday, from 4 to 11 on Saturday and from 4 to 10 on Sunday. Small and noisy but cozy and cheerful, the dining room features autographed photographs of celebrities on the walls, including an Honorary Frank Sinatra Way street sign overhanging the room, and Chicago Cubs banners. But the food, served on white tablecloth, is exceptional. You know you're dining in a special place when so many dishes are described as "best in town." Like cannoli and pasta & fagioli soup and veal. My wife and I started with minestrone, pasta & fagioli with Cannellini beans, pasta and cheese finished with basil and wine, shrimp Armani with shrimp grilled and sauteed in red spicy sauce set over garlic blended with potatoes garnished with argula, and bruschetta with tomatoes, garlic, romano cheese, basil and extra virgin oil served over toasted Italian bread. For entrees, we chose Veal Marsala with Provimi veal and mushrooms flamed with marsala wine and served with a side of pasta and Veal Chop, a 10-ounce veal chop pounded paper thin, breaded and pan fried and finished with garlic, parsley, lemon and extra virgin olive oil and set over dried Italian potatoes. For dessert, we shared large portions of cannoli and tiramisu. Two reminders: valet parking costs only $8. And be sure to purchase a copy of the book, "The Walls of La Scarola," which details the best stories and moments of the restaurant's 20-year history. A visit to La Scarola is a truly special dining experience with a great atmosphere for a bonus.
